001package gbw.melange.common.mesh.formatting.slicing;
002
003import gbw.melange.common.jpms.SPILocator;
004import gbw.melange.common.mesh.formatting.providers.SliceProvider;
005
006import java.util.Spliterator;
007import java.util.function.Consumer;
008
009/**
010 * Represents a slice of a float array for efficient, non-boxing access to a range of floats.
011 * This class is designed for performance-sensitive applications where direct access to
012 * the underlying array's elements is required without the overhead of boxing.<br/>
013 * This is but the parent interface for many, vastly more usefull representations such as
014 * {@link ISliceVec2}, {@link ISliceVec3}, and {@link ISliceVec4} which imitates the behaviour of a vector.<br/>
015 * Note: The implementations does not support spliterator operations. Attempting to
016 * call {@link #spliterator()} will result in a {@link RuntimeException}.
017 *
018 * @author GustavBW
019 */
020public interface IFloatSlice extends Iterable<Float> {
021
022
023
024    /**
025     * Number of components in this reference access vector
026     */
027    int entryWidth();
028    /**
029     * When the series of vector representations was retrieved from the buffer,
030     * that this is a part of, what is the index of the first component of this.
031     */
032    int indexFirstComp();
033
034    /**
035     * Get the value at the index of the slice.
036     * Will throw an {@link ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException} if you try and access indexes not within
037     * this specific slice.
038     * @return float
039     */
040    float get(int index);
041    /**
042     * Set the value at some index in the source through this slice.
043     * @param index of this slice
044     * @param value to set
045     */
046    void set(int index, float value);
047    /**
048     * Any function taking in an unboxed float.
049     * <pre>
050     *     {@code float -> any || Class::method, where args in method: (float name)}
051     * </pre>
052     */
053    @FunctionalInterface
054    interface FloatConsumer {
055        void accept(float value);
056    }
057
058    /**
059     * Iterate over each element in the slice using a method reference / lambda.
060     * Do be aware of the initialization cost of lambdas, so if used in a hot path,
061     * allocate the lambda outside of it or implement a method with signature:
062     * <pre>
063     *     {@code <any> void methodName(float variableName) {...} }
064     * </pre>
065     * And reference it from your code using fx. {@code this::methodName} if defined within the class
066     * where you're calling {@link IFloatSlice#forEachFloat(FloatConsumer)}
067     * @param func What to do with each float
068     */
069    void forEachFloat(FloatConsumer func);
070
071    IFloatSlice copy();
072
073    /**
074     * Don't use this, as this is the generic version and will cause boxing, but is required by the Iterable interface.
075     * Instead, use {@link IFloatSlice#forEachFloat(FloatConsumer)}.
076     * You can help Java sort out its issues by declaring a lambda as of type FloatConsumer, or casting any method reference or lambda.
077     */
078    @Override
079    void forEach(Consumer<? super Float> action);
080
081    /**
082     * Absolutely not supported. Will throw an exception if invoked.
083     * This also rules out processing a single slice using parallel streams.
084     * @throw {@link RuntimeException}
085     * @return nothing
086     */
087    @Override
088    Spliterator<Float> spliterator();
089}
